Earth Information System

Open and Accessible Science to Improve Life on Earth

NASA’s Earth Information System (EIS) harnesses the full power of NASA to answer critical questions about Earth’s System of Systems – past, present and future. To do so, EIS pilots combine models with data from multiple missions and focus areas, and invite collaboration from the global scientific community.

LEARN MORE ABOUT FY21 PILOT STUDIES

FY21 Pilot Studies

Freshwater

Freshwater

Using the Mississippi River Basin as a representative study domain, develop actionable information to support the understanding and management of freshwater availability.


  1.  OVERVIEW OF PILOT
    – EXPLORE MODELS & DATA
    – SEE CASE STUDIES & JUPYTER NOTEBOOKS

Sea Level Change

Sea Level Change

Combine 4 models across 3 science disciplines (cryosphere, oceans, solid earth) to understand how changes to the Greenland Ice Sheet affect sea-level rise on the coast at Hampton Roads, Virginia.


  1.  OVERVIEW OF PILOT
    – SEE CASE STUDIES & JUPYTER NOTEBOOKS

Fire

Fire

Combine datasets from all subdomains of fire science (e.g., active fires, burned area, atmospheric chemistry, fire emissions) to advance the science to track individual fires, estimate fire emissions, and forecast fire risk.


  1.  OVERVIEW OF PILOT
    – SEE CASE STUDIES & JUPYTER NOTEBOOKS

Access NASA’s Earthdata

Earthdata provides easy-to-use access to EOSDIS services for
Earth science data discovery, filtering, visualization, and access.
GET STARTED VISUALIZE DATA FIND DATA

NASA's data policy ensures that all NASA data are available fully, openly, and without restrictions. Here's what this means to you.
